emerging_risks.description: The most rapid growth is occurring in risks related to digital transformation, including cyber liability, digital assets, and AI-related exposures
Climate-related risks are increasingly moving to the E&S market as admitted carriers implement exclusions and restrict coverage in high-risk areas
Risks with unclear regulatory frameworks (cannabis, digital assets) are predominantly placed in the E&S market
Indirect exposures such as supply chain, cloud dependency, and third-party service provider risks are increasingly moving to E&S
Cyber liability represents the largest premium volume among emerging risks at $7.5-8.2B in 2024
ESG liability shows the highest growth rate (70-80% annually), albeit from a smaller base
Emerging risks collectively account for approximately 35-40% of total E&S premium volume
All emerging risk categories show strong double-digit growth, with digital assets and ESG liability growing fastest
Loss ratios vary significantly across emerging risks, from cyber (38-45%) to contingent business interruption (65-75%)
Limited historical data creates underwriting challenges across all emerging risk categories
Some areas performing better than expected (cyber, cannabis), while others show worse results (ESG liability, contingent business interruption)
Legal defense costs represent a disproportionately high percentage of losses in ESG liability and emerging technology risks
Significant admitted market pullback across most emerging risk categories
Some admitted carriers are cautiously testing limited coverage in renewable energy, robotics, and cannabis
New exclusions for specific exposures (ransomware, climate activism, AI liability) are driving risks to the E&S market
AI and machine learning capabilities are essential across all emerging risk categories
Dynamic risk assessment tools that provide continuous monitoring are replacing static underwriting models
Each emerging risk category requires highly specialized technology tools and domain expertise
The ability to integrate diverse data sources (satellite imagery, blockchain data, supply chain information) is critical for effective risk assessment
